cleaned_text: Psychotherapy |Part of a series on| |Psychotherapy| [D011613](https://meshb.nlm.nih.gov/record/ui?ui=D011613) Psychotherapy (also psychological therapy, talk therapy, or talking therapy) is the use of [psychological](/wiki/Psychology) methods, particularly when based on regular [personal interaction](/wiki/Conversation), to help a person change behavior, increase happiness, and overcome problems. Psychotherapy aims to improve an individual's [well-being](/wiki/Well-being) and [mental health](/wiki/Mental_health), to resolve or mitigate troublesome behaviors, beliefs, compulsions, thoughts, or emotions, and to improve relationships and [social skills](/wiki/Social_skills). [[1]](#cite_note-1) Numerous types of psychotherapy have been designed either for individual adults, families, or children and adolescents. Certain types of psychotherapy are considered [evidence-based](/wiki/Evidence-based) for treating some diagnosed [mental disorders](/wiki/Mental_disorder); other types have been criticized as [pseudoscience](/wiki/Pseudoscience). [[2]](#cite_note-2) There are hundreds of psychotherapy techniques, some being minor variations; others are based on very different conceptions of psychology. [[3]](#cite_note-3) Most involve one-to-one sessions, between the client and therapist, but some are conducted with [groups](/wiki/Group_psychotherapy), [[4]](#cite_note-4) including [families](/wiki/Family_therapy). Psychotherapists may be [mental health professionals](/wiki/Mental_health_professionals) such as psychiatrists, psychologists, mental health nurses, clinical social workers, marriage and family therapists, or professional counselors. Psychotherapists may also come from a variety of other backgrounds, and depending on the [jurisdiction](/wiki/Jurisdiction) may be legally regulated, voluntarily regulated or unregulated (and the term itself may be protected or not). Definitions[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Psychotherapy&action=edit§ion=1)] The term [psychotherapy](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/psychotherapy) Dictionary](/wiki/Oxford_English_Dictionary) defines it as "The treatment of disorders of the mind or personality by psychological means...", however, in earlier use it denoted the treatment of disease through hypnotic suggestion. [[5]](#cite_note-OED-5) Psychotherapy is often dubbed as a "talking therapy" or "talk therapy", particularly for a general audience, [[6]](#cite_note-6) though not all forms of psychotherapy rely on [verbal communication](/wiki/Verbal_communication). [[7]](#cite_note-7) Children or adults who do not engage in verbal communication (or not in the usual way) are not excluded from psychotherapy; indeed some types are designed for such cases. The [American Psychological Association](/wiki/American_Psychological_Association) adopted a resolution on the effectiveness of psychotherapy in 2012 based on a definition developed by American psychologist [John C. Norcross](/wiki/John_C._Norcross): "Psychotherapy is the informed and intentional application of [clinical methods](/wiki/Clinical_psychology) and [interpersonal stances](/wiki/Interpersonal_relationship) derived from established psychological principles for the purpose of assisting people to modify their behaviors, cognitions, emotions, and/or other personal characteristics in directions that the participants deem desirable". [[8]](#cite_note-resolution-8) [[9]](#cite_note-9) Influential editions of a work by psychiatrist [Jerome Frank](/wiki/Jerome_Frank_(psychiatrist)) defined psychotherapy as a healing relationship using socially authorized methods in a series of contacts primarily involving words, acts and rituals—which Frank regarded as forms of [persuasion](/wiki/Persuasion) and [rhetoric](/wiki/Rhetoric). [[10]](#cite_note-10) Historically, psychotherapy has sometimes meant "interpretative" (i.e. [Freudian](/wiki/Freudian)) methods, namely [psychoanalysis](/wiki/Psychoanalysis), in contrast with other methods to treat psychiatric disorders such as behavior modification. [[11]](#cite_note-11) Some definitions of [counseling](/wiki/Counseling) overlap with psychotherapy (particularly in non-directive client-centered approaches), or counseling may refer to guidance for everyday problems in specific areas, typically for shorter durations with a less medical or "professional" focus. [[12]](#cite_note-12) [Somatotherapy](/wiki/Somatotherapy) refers to the use of physical changes as injuries and illnesses, and [sociotherapy](/wiki/Sociotherapy) to the use of a person's social environment to effect therapeutic change. [[13]](#cite_note-13) Psychotherapy may address [spirituality](/wiki/Spirituality) as a significant part of someone's mental / psychological life, and some forms are derived from spiritual philosophies, but practices based on treating the spiritual as a separate dimension are not necessarily considered as traditional or 'legitimate' forms of psychotherapy. [[14]](#cite_note-14) Delivery[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Psychotherapy&action=edit§ion=2)] Psychotherapy may be delivered in person (one on one, or with couples, or in groups) or via [telephone counseling](/wiki/Telephone_counseling) or [online counseling](/wiki/Online_counseling) (see also [§ Telepsychotherapy](#Telepsychotherapy)). [[15]](#cite_note-Wright2008-15) There have also been developments in computer-assisted therapy, such as [virtual reality therapy](/wiki/Virtual_reality_therapy) for behavioral exposure, multimedia programs to teach cognitive techniques, and handheld devices for improved monitoring or putting ideas into practice (see also [§ Computer-supported](#Computer-supported)). [[15]](#cite_note-Wright2008-15) [[16]](#cite_note-16) Most forms of psychotherapy use spoken [conversation](/wiki/Conversation). Some also use various other forms of communication such as the written word, [artwork](/wiki/Work_of_art), [drama](/wiki/Drama), [narrative](/wiki/Narrative) story or music. Psychotherapy with children and their parents often involves [play](/wiki/Play_(activity)), dramatization (i.e. role-play), and drawing, with a co-constructed narrative from these non-verbal and displaced modes of interacting. [[17]](#cite_note-17) Regulation[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Psychotherapy&action=edit§ion=3)] Psychotherapists traditionally may be [mental health professionals](/wiki/Mental_health_professionals) like psychologists and psychiatrists; professionals from other backgrounds (family therapists, social workers, nurses, etc.) who have trained in a specific psychotherapy; or (in some cases) academic or scientifically trained professionals. [Psychiatrists](/wiki/Psychiatrists) are trained first as physicians, and as such they may prescribe [prescription medication](/wiki/Drugs); and specialist psychiatric training begins after medical school in psychiatric residencies: however, their specialty is in mental disorders or forms of mental illness. [[18]](#cite_note-18) [Clinical psychologists](/wiki/Clinical_psychology) have specialist doctoral degrees in psychology with some clinical and research components. Other clinical practitioners, [social workers](/wiki/Social_workers), mental health counselors, pastoral counselors, and nurses with a specialization in mental health, also often conduct psychotherapy. Many of the wide variety of psychotherapy training programs and institutional settings are multi-professional. In most countries, psychotherapy training is completed at a postgraduate level, often at a master's degree (or doctoral) level, over four years, with significant supervised practice and clinical placements. Mental health professionals that choose to specialize in psychotherapeutic work also require a program of continuing professional education after basic professional training. [[19]](#cite_note-19) A listing of the extensive professional competencies of a European psychotherapist was developed by the European Association of Psychotherapy (EAP) in 2013. [[20]](#cite_note-20) As sensitive and deeply personal topics are often discussed during psychotherapy, therapists are expected, and usually legally bound, to respect client or patient confidentiality. The critical importance of [client confidentiality](/wiki/Client_confidentiality)—and the limited circumstances in which it may need to be broken for the protection of clients or others—is enshrined in the regulatory psychotherapeutic organizations' codes of ethical practice. [[21]](#cite_note-21) Examples of when it is typically accepted to break confidentiality include when the therapist has knowledge that a child or elder is being physically abused; when there is a direct, clear and imminent threat of serious physical harm to self or to a specific individual. Europe[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Psychotherapy&action=edit§ion=4)] As of 2015, there are still a lot of variations between different European countries about the regulation and delivery of psychotherapy. Several countries have no regulation of the practice or no protection of the title. Some have a system of voluntary registration, with independent professional organizations, while other countries attempt to restrict the practice of psychotherapy to 'mental health professionals' (psychologists and psychiatrists) with state-certified training. The titles that are protected also vary. [[22]](#cite_note-Woelbert-22) The [European Association for Psychotherapy](/wiki/European_Association_for_Psychotherapy) (EAP) established the 1990 Strasbourg Declaration on Psychotherapy, which is dedicated to establishing an independent profession of psychotherapy in Europe, with pan-European standards. [[23]](#cite_note-23) The EAP has already made significant contacts with the European Union & European Commission towards this end. Given that the [European Union](/wiki/European_Union) has a primary policy about the free movement of labor within Europe, European legislation can overrule national regulations that are, in essence, forms of restrictive practices. In Germany, the practice of psychotherapy for adults is restricted to qualified psychologists and physicians (including psychiatrists) who have completed several years of specialist practical training and certification in psychotherapy. As psychoanalysis, psychodynamic therapy, and cognitive behavioral therapy meet the requirements of German health insurance companies, mental health professionals regularly opt for one of these three specializations in their postgraduate training. For psychologists, this includes three years of full-time practical training (4,200 hours), encompassing a year-long internship at an accredited psychiatric institution, six months of clinical work at an outpatient facility, 600 hours of supervised psychotherapy in an outpatient setting, and at least 600 hours of theoretical seminars. [[24]](#cite_note-24) [Social workers](/wiki/Social_worker) may complete the specialist training for child and teenage clients. [[25]](#cite_note-25) Similarly in Italy, the practice of psychotherapy is restricted to graduates in psychology or medicine who have completed four years of recognised specialist training. [[26]](#cite_note-26) [[27]](#cite_note-27) Sweden has a similar restriction on the title "psychotherapist", which may only be used by professionals who have gone through a post-graduate training in psychotherapy and then applied for a licence, issued by the [National Board of Health and Welfare](/wiki/National_Board_of_Health_and_Welfare_(Sweden)). [[28]](#cite_note-28) Legislation in France restricts the use of the title "psychotherapist" to professionals on the National Register of Psychotherapists, [[29]](#cite_note-29) which requires a training in clinical psychopathology and a period of internship which is only open to physicians or titulars of a master's degree in psychology or psychoanalysis.[ [citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)] Austria and Switzerland (2011) have laws that recognize multi-disciplinary functional approaches.[ [citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)] In the United Kingdom, the government and [Health and Care Professions Council](/wiki/Health_and_Care_Professions_Council) considered mandatory legal registration but decided that it was best left to professional bodies to regulate themselves, so the [Professional Standards Authority for Health and Social Care](/wiki/Professional_Standards_Authority_for_Health_and_Social_Care) (PSA) launched an Accredited Voluntary Registers scheme. [[30]](#cite_note-30) [[31]](#cite_note-31) [[32]](#cite_note-32) [[33]](#cite_note-33) [[34]](#cite_note-34) Counseling and psychotherapy are not protected titles in the United Kingdom. Counsellors and psychotherapists who have trained and qualify to a certain standard (usually a level 4 Diploma) can apply to be members of the professional bodies who are listed on the PSA Accredited Registers. United States[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Psychotherapy&action=edit§ion=5)] In some states, counselors or therapists must be licensed to use certain words and titles on self-identification or advertising. In some other states, the restrictions on practice are more closely associated with the charging of fees. Licensing and regulation are performed by various states. Presentation of practice as licensed, but without such a license, is generally illegal. [[35]](#cite_note-35) Without a license, for example, a practitioner cannot bill insurance companies. [[36]](#cite_note-36) Information about state licensure is provided by the [American Psychological Association](/wiki/American_Psychological_Association). [[37]](#cite_note-37) In addition to state laws, the American Psychological Association requires its members to adhere to its published Ethical Principles of Psychologists and Code of Conduct. [[38]](#cite_note-38) The [American Board of Professional Psychology](/wiki/American_Board_of_Professional_Psychology) examines and certifies "psychologists who demonstrate competence in approved specialty areas in professional psychology". [[39]](#cite_note-39) Canada[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Psychotherapy&action=edit§ion=6)] Regulation of psychotherapy is in the jurisdiction of, and varies among, the provinces and territories. In [Quebec](/wiki/Quebec), psychotherapy is a regulated activity which is restricted to psychologists, medical doctors, and holders of a psychotherapy permit issued by the Ordre des psychologues du Québec, the Quebec order of psychologists. Members of certain specified professions, including [social workers](/wiki/Social_work), couple [sexologists](/wiki/Sexology), [psychoeducators](/wiki/Psychoeducation), and registered nurses may obtain a psychotherapy permit by completing certain educational and practice requirements; their professional oversight is provided by their own professional orders. Some other professionals who were practising psychotherapy before the current system came into force continue to hold psychotherapy permits alone. [[40]](#cite_note-40) On 1 July 2019, Ontario's Missing Persons Act came into effect, with the purpose of giving police more power to investigate missing persons. It allows police to require (as opposed to permit) health professionals, including psychotherapists, to share otherwise confidential documents about their client, if there is reason to believe their client is missing. [[41]](#cite_note-41) [[42]](#cite_note-42) Some have expressed concern that this legislation undermines psychotherapy confidentiality and could be abused maliciously by police, [[43]](#cite_note-43) while others have praised the act for how it respects privacy and includes checks and balances. [[44]](#cite_note-44) History[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Psychotherapy&action=edit§ion=7)] Psychotherapy can be said to have been practiced through the ages, as medics, philosophers, spiritual practitioners and people in general used psychological methods to heal others. [[45]](#cite_note-45) [[46]](#cite_note-46) In the [Western tradition](/wiki/Western_culture), by the 19th century, a [moral treatment](/wiki/Moral_treatment) movement (then meaning morale or mental) developed based on non-invasive non-restraint therapeutic methods. [[47]](#cite_note-47) Another influential movement was started by [Franz Mesmer](/wiki/Franz_Mesmer) (1734-1815) his Puységur](/wiki/Armand-Marie-Jacques_de_Chastenet,_Marquis_of_Puys%C3%A9gur) (1751-1825). Called Mesmerism or animal magnetism, it would have a strong influence on the rise of [dynamic psychology](/wiki/Dynamic_psychology) and psychiatry as well as theories about [hypnosis](/wiki/Hypnosis). [[48]](#cite_note-48) [[49]](#cite_note-49) In 1853, [Walter Cooper Dendy](/wiki/Walter_Cooper_Dendy) introduced the term "psycho-therapeia" regarding how physicians might influence the mental states of patients and thus their bodily ailments, for example by creating opposing emotions to promote mental balance. [[50]](#cite_note-50) [[51]](#cite_note-51) [Daniel Hack Tuke](/wiki/Daniel_Hack_Tuke) cited the term and wrote about "psycho-therapeutics" in 1872, in which he also proposed making a science of [animal magnetism](/wiki/Animal_magnetism). [[52]](#cite_note-Shamdasani-52) [[53]](#cite_note-53) [Hippolyte Bernheim](/wiki/Hippolyte_Bernheim) and colleagues [Nancy](/wiki/Nancy,_France) School" developed the concept of "psychotherapy" in the sense of using the mind to heal the body through [hypnotism](/wiki/Hypnotism), yet further. [[52]](#cite_note-Shamdasani-52) Charles Lloyd Tuckey's 1889 work, Psycho-therapeutics, or Treatment by Hypnotism and Suggestion popularized the work of the Nancy School in English. [[52]](#cite_note-Shamdasani-52) [[54]](#cite_note-54) Also in 1889 a clinic used the word in its title for the first time, when [Frederik van Eeden](/wiki/Frederik_van_Eeden) and Albert Willem van Renterghem in [Amsterdam](/wiki/Amsterdam) renamed theirs "Clinique de Psycho-thérapeutique Suggestive" after visiting Nancy. [[52]](#cite_note-Shamdasani-52) During this time, travelling [stage hypnosis](/wiki/Stage_hypnosis) became popular, and such activities added to the scientific controversies around the use of hypnosis in medicine. [[52]](#cite_note-Shamdasani-52) Also in 1892, at the second congress of experimental psychology, van Eeden attempted to take the credit for the term psychotherapy and to distance the term from hypnosis. [[52]](#cite_note-Shamdasani-52) In 1896, the probably the first journal to use the term. [[52]](#cite_note-Shamdasani-52) Thus psychotherapy initially meant "the treatment of disease by psychic or hypnotic influence, or by suggestion". [[5]](#cite_note-OED-5) [Sigmund Freud](/wiki/Sigmund_Freud) visited the Nancy School and his early [neurological](/wiki/Neurological) practice involved the use of hypnotism. However following the work of his mentor [Josef Breuer](/wiki/Josef_Breuer)—in particular a case where symptoms appeared partially resolved by what the patient, [Bertha Pappenheim](/wiki/Bertha_Pappenheim), dubbed a " [talking cure](/wiki/Talking_cure)"—Freud began focusing on conditions that appeared to have psychological causes originating in childhood experiences and the [unconscious mind](/wiki/Unconscious_mind). He went on to develop techniques such as [free association](/wiki/Free_association_(psychology)), [dream interpretation](/wiki/Dream_interpretation), [transference](/wiki/Transference) and analysis of the [id, ego and superego](/wiki/Id,_ego_and_superego). His popular reputation as the father of psychotherapy was established by his use of the distinct term " [psychoanalysis](/wiki/Psychoanalysis)", tied to an overarching system of theories and methods, and by the effective work of his followers in rewriting history. [[52]](#cite_note-Shamdasani-52) Many Freud's fundamental ideas and often developed their own systems of psychotherapy. These were all later categorized as [psychodynamic](/wiki/Psychodynamic), meaning anything that involved the [psyche](/wiki/Psyche_(psychology))'s [conscious](/wiki/Conscious)/ [unconscious](/wiki/Unconscious_mind) influence on external relationships and the self. Sessions tended to number into the hundreds over several years. [Behaviorism](/wiki/Behaviorism) developed in the 1920s, and [behavior modification](/wiki/Behavior_modification) as a therapy became popularized in the 1950s and 1960s. Notable contributors were [Joseph Wolpe](/wiki/Joseph_Wolpe) in South Africa, [M.B. Shapiro](/wiki/Monte_B._Shapiro) Skinner](/wiki/B.F._Skinner) in the United States. of [operant conditioning](/wiki/Operant_conditioning), [classical conditioning](/wiki/Classical_conditioning) and [social learning theory](/wiki/Social_learning_theory) to bring about therapeutic change in observable symptoms. The approach became commonly used for [phobias](/wiki/Phobias), as well as other disorders. [[56]](#cite_note-56) Some therapeutic approaches developed out of the European school of [existential philosophy](/wiki/Existential_philosophy). Concerned mainly with the individual's ability to develop and preserve a sense of meaning and purpose throughout life, major contributors to the field (e.g., [Irvin therapies sensitive to common "life crises" springing from the essential bleakness of human self-awareness, previously accessible only through the complex writings of existential relationship](/wiki/Therapeutic_relationship) thus also forms a vehicle for therapeutic inquiry. A related body of thought in psychotherapy started in the 1950s with [Carl Rogers](/wiki/Carl_Rogers). Based also on the works of [Abraham Maslow](/wiki/Abraham_Maslow) and his [hierarchy of human needs](/wiki/Hierarchy_of_human_needs), Rogers brought [person-centered psychotherapy](/wiki/Person-centered_psychotherapy) into mainstream focus. The primary requirement was that the client receive three core "conditions" from his counselor or therapist: unconditional positive regard, sometimes described as "prizing" the client's humanity; congruence [authenticity/genuineness/transparency]; and [empathic understanding](/wiki/Empathy). This type of interaction was thought to enable clients to fully experience and express themselves, and thus develop according to their innate potential. [[57]](#cite_note-57) Others developed the approach, like [Fritz](/wiki/Fritz_Perls) and [Laura Perls](/wiki/Laura_Perls) in the creation of [Gestalt therapy](/wiki/Gestalt_therapy), as well as Marshall Rosenberg, founder of [Nonviolent Communication](/wiki/Nonviolent_Communication), and [Eric Berne](/wiki/Eric_Berne), founder of [transactional analysis](/wiki/Transactional_analysis). Later these fields of psychotherapy would become what is known as [humanistic psychotherapy](/wiki/Humanistic_psychology) today. Self-help groups and books became widespread. During 1950s, [Albert Ellis](/wiki/Albert_Ellis_(psychologist)) originated [rational emotive behavior therapy](/wiki/Rational_emotive_behavior_therapy) (REBT). Independently a few years later, psychiatrist [Aaron T. Beck](/wiki/Aaron_T._Beck) developed a form of psychotherapy known as [cognitive therapy](/wiki/Cognitive_therapy). Both of these included relatively short, structured and present-focused techniques aimed at identifying and changing a person's beliefs, appraisals and reaction-patterns, by contrast with the more long-lasting insight-based approach of psychodynamic or humanistic therapies. Beck's approach used primarily the [socratic method](/wiki/Socratic_method), and links have been drawn between ancient [stoic](/wiki/Stoicism) philosophy and these cognitive therapies. [[58]](#cite_note-RobertsonUS952010-58) Cognitive and behavioral therapy approaches were increasingly combined and grouped under the umbrella term [cognitive behavioral therapy](/wiki/Cognitive_behavioral_therapy) (CBT) in the 1970s. Many approaches within CBT are oriented towards active/directive yet collaborative [empiricism](/wiki/Empiricism) (a form of reality-testing), and assessing and modifying core beliefs and dysfunctional schemas. These approaches gained widespread acceptance as a primary treatment for numerous disorders. A "third wave" of cognitive and behavioral therapies developed, including [acceptance and commitment therapy](/wiki/Acceptance_and_commitment_therapy) and [dialectical behavior therapy](/wiki/Dialectical_behavior_therapy), which expanded the concepts to other disorders and/or added novel components and [mindfulness](/wiki/Mindfulness_(psychology)) exercises. However the "third wave" concept has been criticized as not essentially different from other therapies and having roots in earlier ones as well. [[59]](#cite_note-59) Counseling methods developed include [solution-focused [coherence therapy](/wiki/Coherence_therapy) do not impose definitions of mental health and illness, but rather see the goal of therapy as something constructed by the client and therapist in a social context. [Systemic therapy](/wiki/Systemic_therapy) also developed, which focuses on family and group dynamics—and [transpersonal psychology](/wiki/Transpersonal_psychology), which focuses on the spiritual facet of human experience. Other orientations developed in the last three decades include givens](/wiki/Human_givens) approach. A survey of over 2,500 US therapists in 2006 revealed the most utilized models of therapy and the ten most influential therapists of the previous quarter-century. [[60]](#cite_note-60) Types[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Psychotherapy&action=edit§ion=8)] There are hundreds of psychotherapy approaches or schools of thought. By 1980 there were more than 250; [[61]](#cite_note-61) by 1996 more than 450; [[62]](#cite_note-62) and at the start of the 21st century there were over a thousand different named psychotherapies—some being minor variations while others are based on very different conceptions of psychology, ethics (how to live) or technique. [[63]](#cite_note-lebow-63) [[64]](#cite_note-64) In practice therapy is often not of one pure type but draws from a number of perspectives and schools—known as an [integrative](/wiki/Integrative_psychotherapy) or [eclectic](/wiki/Eclectic_psychotherapy) approach. [[65]](#cite_note-65) [[66]](#cite_note-66) The importance of the [therapeutic relationship](/wiki/Therapeutic_relationship), also known as therapeutic alliance, between client and therapist is often regarded as crucial to psychotherapy. [Common factors theory](/wiki/Common_factors_theory) addresses this and other core aspects thought to be responsible for effective psychotherapy. Sigmund Freud (1856-1939), a Viennese neurologist who studied with [Jean-Martin Charcot](/wiki/Jean-Martin_Charcot) in 1885, is often considered the father of modern psychotherapy. His methods included analyzing his patient's dreams in search of important hidden insights into their unconscious minds. Other major elements of his methods, which changed throughout the years, included identification of childhood sexuality, the role of anxiety as a manifestation of inner conflict, the differentiation of parts of the psyche (id, ego, superego), transference and countertransference (the patient's projections onto the therapist, and the therapist's emotional responses to that). Some of his concepts were too broad to be amenable to empirical testing and invalidation, and he was critiqued for this by Jaspers. Numerous major figures elaborated and refined Freud's therapeutic techniques including Melanie Klein, Donald Winnicott, and others. Since the 1960s, however, the use of Freudian-based analysis for the treatment of [mental disorders](/wiki/Mental_disorder) has declined substantially. Different types of psychotherapy have been created along with the advent of clinical trials to test them scientifically. These incorporate subjective treatments (after Beck), behavioral treatments (after Skinner and Wolpe) and additional time-constrained and centered structures, for example, interpersonal psychotherapy. In youth issue and in schizophrenia, the systems of family treatment hold esteem. A portion of the thoughts emerging from therapy are presently pervasive and some are a piece of the tool set of ordinary clinical practice. They are not just medications, they additionally help to understand complex conduct. Therapy may address specific forms of diagnosable [mental illness](/wiki/Mental_illness), or everyday problems in managing or maintaining [interpersonal relationships](/wiki/Interpersonal_relationships) or meeting personal goals. A course of therapy may happen before, during or after [pharmacotherapy](/wiki/Pharmacotherapy) (e.g. taking [psychiatric medication](/wiki/Psychiatric_medication)). Psychotherapies are categorized in several different ways. A distinction can be made between those based on a [medical model](/wiki/Medical_model) and those based on a [humanistic model](/wiki/Humanistic_psychology). In the medical model, the client is seen as unwell and the therapist employs their skill to help the client back to health. The extensive use of the [DSM-IV](/wiki/DSM-IV), the diagnostic and statistical manual of mental disorders in the United States is an example of a medically exclusive model. The humanistic or non-medical model in contrast strives to depathologise the human condition. The therapist attempts to create a relational environment conducive to experiential learning and help build the client's confidence in their own natural process resulting in a deeper understanding of themselves. The therapist may see themselves as a facilitator/helper. Another distinction is between individual one-to-one therapy sessions, psychotherapy](/wiki/Group_psychotherapy), including [couples therapy](/wiki/Couples_therapy) and [family therapy](/wiki/Family_therapy). [[67]](#cite_note-67) Therapies sometimes classified according to their duration; a small number of sessions over a few weeks or months may be classified as [brief therapy](/wiki/Brief_therapy) (or short-term therapy), others, where regular sessions take place for years, may be classified as long-term. Some practitioners distinguish between more "uncovering" (or " [depth](/wiki/Depth_psychology)") approaches and more "supportive" psychotherapy. Uncovering psychotherapy emphasizes facilitating the client's insight into the roots of their difficulties. The best-known example is classical psychoanalysis. [Supportive psychotherapy](/wiki/Supportive_psychotherapy) by contrast stresses strengthening the client's coping mechanisms and often providing encouragement and advice, as well as reality-testing and limit-setting where necessary. Depending on the client's issues and situation, a more supportive or more uncovering approach may be optimal. [[68]](#cite_note-68) Humanistic[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Psychotherapy&action=edit§ion=9)] These psychotherapies, also known as " [experiential](/wiki/Experiential_knowledge)", are based on [humanistic psychology](/wiki/Humanistic_psychology) and emerged in reaction to both behaviorism and psychoanalysis, being dubbed the "third force". They are primarily concerned with the human development and needs of the individual, with an emphasis on [subjective](/wiki/Subjectivity) meaning, a rejection of [determinism](/wiki/Determinism), and a concern for positive growth rather than [pathology](/wiki/Pathology). [[69]](#cite_note-69) Some posit an inherent human capacity to maximize potential, "the [self-actualizing](/wiki/Self-actualization) tendency"; the task of therapy is to create a relational environment where this tendency might flourish. [[70]](#cite_note-70) Humanistic psychology can, in turn, be rooted in [existentialism](/wiki/Existentialism)—the belief that human beings can only find meaning by creating it. This is the goal of [existential therapy](/wiki/Existential_therapy). Existential therapy is in turn philosophically associated with [phenomenology](/wiki/Phenomenology_(philosophy)). [[71]](#cite_note-71) [[72]](#cite_note-72) [Person-centered therapy](/wiki/Person-centered_therapy), also known as client-centered, focuses on the therapist showing openness, empathy and "unconditional positive regard", to help clients express and develop their own [self](/wiki/Self). [[73]](#cite_note-73) Humanistic [Psychodrama](/wiki/Psychodrama) (HPD) is based on the human image of humanistic psychology. [[74]](#cite_note-74) So all rules and methods follow the axioms of humanistic psychology. The HPD sees itself as development-oriented psychotherapy and has completely moved away from the psychoanalytic catharsis theory. [[75]](#cite_note-75) Self-awareness and self-realization are essential aspects in the therapeutic process. Subjective experiences, feelings and thoughts and one's own experiences are the starting point for a change or reorientation in experience and behavior in the direction of more self-acceptance and satisfaction. Dealing with the biography of the individual is closely related to the sociometry of the group. [[76]](#cite_note-76) [Gestalt therapy](/wiki/Gestalt_therapy), originally called "concentration therapy", is an existential/experiential form that facilitates awareness in the various contexts of life, by moving from talking about relatively remote situations to action and direct current experience. Derived from various influences, including an overhaul of psychoanalysis, it stands on top of essentially four load-bearing theoretical walls: [phenomenological method](/wiki/Phenomenology_(psychology)), dialogical relationship, field-theoretical freedom. briefer form of humanistic therapy is the [human givens](/wiki/Human_givens) approach, introduced in 1998-99. [[78]](#cite_note-78) It is a solution-focused intervention based on identifying emotional needs—such as for security, autonomy and social connection—and using various educational and psychological methods to help people meet those needs more fully or appropriately.
